abstract: The two companies, partners of the enterprise software maker, will take ownership stakes in the biggest leveraged buyout of the year.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — As Informatica closes its $5.3 billion sale to private equity on Thursday, the enterprise software maker will count two of its big technology partners as new investors as well.
headline: Salesforce Ventures and Microsoft Join Informatica Buyout

abstract: The Never-Ending Lawsuit | Why Disclosing C.E.O. Pay Might Bring Change | Apollo’s Stake in American Realty
lead_para: ACKMAN’S BET ON MONDELEZ SALES | By building up a $5.5 billion stake in Mondelez International, William A. Ackman is wagering that Mondelez could be persuaded to sell itself, Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook. The investment that Mr. Ackman’s Pershing Square Capital Management has made also highlights the widespread belief that the food sector is ripe for consolidation.
headline: Morning Agenda: Ackman’s Bet on Mondelez Sales

abstract: As stocks slumped on Thursday, some technology companies took particularly bad hits, both during regular trading hours and even afterward.
lead_para: Nearly everything on the stock market fell on Thursday, with some tech companies taking particularly hard hits.
headline: Daily Report: The Stock Market Carnage Cometh for Tech

abstract: A well-known programmer says he’s building advanced data analysis that thousands of companies could use on the cloud-computing platform provided by Salesforce.com.
lead_para: Salesforce.com was one of the early giants of the cloud-computing revolution. Now it wants to be at the center of two of the next big things — big data and so-called computational intelligence everywhere.
headline: Salesforce Plans to Give Customers Amazon-Type Analytics

abstract: An industry with a long history of supporting gay rights is starting to speak out against a new Indiana law that gives legal cover to people who refuse to do business with same-sex couples.
lead_para: The tech industry is applying its economic muscle well outside of Silicon Valley.
headline: Tech Executives Pressure Indiana After Passage of Controversial Law

abstract: In an industry that avoids controversy, the heads of several prominent companies, including Apple and Salesforce.com, have chosen to pick a battle.
lead_para: The technology industry’s leaders have found their collective voice on a social issue in the last week, rallying with great intensity against a new Indiana law that will allow businesses, they predict, to discriminate against gay couples. The heads of Apple, Salesforce.com, Yelp and Square have all publicly criticized the law, as have some leaders from other industries.
headline: Silicon Valley Leaders, New to Social Issues, Come Together Over Indiana Law

abstract: Buying the cloud-based customer-service software could make businesses less likely to ditch Office. It might, however, cost Microsoft some $60 billion.
lead_para: Would Microsoft really want to own Salesforce.com?
headline: Would Salesforce Make Sense for Microsoft?

abstract: More than three dozen chief executives and other senior Silicon Valley leaders issued a joint statement asking all state legislatures to add sexual orientation and gender identity as protected classes to their civil rights laws.
lead_para: Technology leaders are looking beyond an Indiana battle over gay rights that united them in the past week, and are calling on all states to enact anti-discrimination protections for lesbians, gay, bisexual and transgender people.
headline: Tech Leaders Call for Anti-Discrimination Laws to Protect Gays in all 50 States

abstract: Oracle and Microsoft want to increase cloud capacity, making them possible suitors.
lead_para: Salesforce.com’s slowing growth makes this a good time to seek a suitor. The $47 billion software outfit is on the market, according to Bloomberg.
headline: Salesforce’s Slow Growth May Prompt Hunt for a Buyer

abstract: In an industry that avoids controversy, the heads of several prominent companies, including Apple and Salesforce.com, have chosen to pick a battle.
lead_para: The technology industry’s leaders have found their collective voice on a social issue in the last week, rallying with great intensity against a new Indiana law that will allow businesses, they predict, to discriminate against gay couples. The heads of Apple, Salesforce.com, Yelp and Square have all publicly criticized the law, as have some leaders from other industries.
headline: Daily Report: Tech Leaders Come Together to Oppose Indiana Law

abstract: Corporations were right to speak out on this issue. They should take the same stand with their campaign spending.
lead_para: Big corporations like Walmart, Apple, Salesforce.com and General Electric and their executives have done the right thing by calling on officials in Indiana and Arkansas to reject “religious freedom” laws designed to give businesses and religious groups legal cover should they deny service to gay couples. But the business response to these laws raises a larger issue about the role companies play in the political process. If corporate leaders are serious in opposing discrimination, they should refuse to finance the campaigns of lawmakers who want to deny civil rights to gays and other minority groups.
headline: Big Business and Anti-Gay Laws

abstract: A troubling aspect of the exuberance for technology stocks is the degree to which companies promote financial results and measures that exclude the actual costs of doing business.
lead_para: Technology shares have been powering the stock market recently, outperforming the broader stock indexes by wide margins. The tech-heavy Nasdaq 100, for example, is up 19 percent over the last 12 months, almost twice as much as the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, which has risen 10 percent.
headline: Tech Companies Fly High on Fantasy Accounting

abstract: The company’s chief executive, Marc Benioff, started the Women’s Surge program to achieve gender equality in pay and promotion and to get more diversity at meetings.
lead_para: Marc Benioff, the co-founder and chief executive of Salesforce, was riding high a couple of years ago. His cloud software company had weathered the financial crisis, revenue was up, and the stock was at a record high.
headline: Salesforce Makes Strides Toward Gender Equality in Silicon Valley

abstract: Deutsche Bank Triples Net Profit | On Track for a September Rate Rise | Puerto Rico’s Next Big Test
lead_para: STEADY AS SHE GOES AT FACEBOOK | The social network beat Wall Street expectations in the second quarter, with revenue up 39 percent from a year ago to $4.04 billion, Vindu Goel reports in The New York Times. Net income was down to $719 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $791 million, or 30 cents a share, a year ago.
headline: Morning Agenda: Steady as She Goes at Facebook

abstract: Mr. Benioff runs Salesforce.com with a “1-1-1” philosophy, annually donating 1 percent of its equity, 1 percent of its employee time and 1 percent of its product to nonprofits. He explains why.
lead_para: Marc Benioff founded Salesforce.com, one of the first and most successful cloud computing software companies, in 1999. The stock has gained over 1,800 percent since the company went public in 2004, making Mr. Benioff, a onetime Oracle executive, a billionaire.
headline: Marc Benioff, Salesforce Chief, on the Strategic Benefits of Corporate Giving

abstract: Uber Waves the White Flag | Big Banks Push Instant Payments
lead_para: HERBALIFE VS. ACTIVIST: JUST MAYBE HE’S RIGHT Bill Ackman, the activist investor, has been painted as a loser in his quest to shut down Herbalife, the nutritional supplement company, but a Federal Trade Commission’s complaint has vindicated his claims, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes.
headline: Morning Agenda: Herbalife vs. Activist: Just Maybe He’s Right

abstract: European regulators look at Microsoft’s purchase of LinkedIn not for what it is, but for what may be. They are right to.
lead_para: European regulators may be starting to regard antitrust in the tech industry in the light of the famous line about pornography: They can’t define it, but they know it when they see it.
headline: Daily Report: Trust Busters Destined to Dig into Data

abstract: Salesforce, a San Francisco tech company, is said to have questioned whether Microsoft’s takeover of LinkedIn might hinder consumer choice and access to data.
lead_para: Microsoft outmuscled its rival Salesforce.com this year to buy LinkedIn, the professional social network, for $26.2 billion.
headline: Salesforce Is Said to Question Microsoft-LinkedIn Deal in Europe

abstract: As G.E., Oracle, Salesforce.com and others push their A.I. products, it remains unclear whether potential customers understand how they will profit.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — This is the year artificial intelligence came into its own for mainstream businesses, at least as a marketing feature.
headline: Artificial Intelligence Software Is Booming. But Why Now?

abstract: The social network site has been considering a possible restructuring as it wrestles with a slowdown in its growth.
lead_para: Twitter has long positioned itself as a global town square where anyone — celebrities, politicians, athletes, and you and me — can chat in 140-character messages and find out about whatever is happening in the moment.
headline: Twitter Is Said to Be Discussing a Possible Takeover

abstract: A possible takeover shows that just what Twitter is still is very much in the eye of the beholder.
lead_para: Twitter has some 300 million regular monthly users — and possibly as many views about the company’s long-term purpose and value.
headline: Daily Report: Twitter Attracts a Wide Range of Suitors

abstract: “Twitter has received expressions of interest from a number of technology companies,” said David Faber of CNBC, including from Salesforce.com and Google.
lead_para: “Twitter has received expressions of interest from a number of technology companies,” said David Faber of CNBC, including from Salesforce.com and Google.
headline: Twitter Moving Closer to Sale

abstract: As the stock market continues its 2016 slide, technology stocks are falling even further, victims partly of their own success.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — As the United States economy muddled along over the last few years, investors paid handsome sums to get in on high-flying technology companies that were among the few pockets of steady growth. Now comes the payback.
headline: Tech Stocks Have Fallen Faster and Further Than Broader Market

abstract: Marc Benioff, chairman and chief executive of Salesforce, discussed at The New York Times’s New Work Summit how his company has tried to provide more and better opportunities for women.
lead_para: Marc Benioff, chairman and chief executive of Salesforce, discussed at The New York Times’s New Work Summit how his company has tried to provide more and better opportunities for women.
headline: Salesforce’s ‘Women’s Surge’

abstract: Salesforce, itself a cloud-computing company, will use Amazon Web Services to grow more rapidly in a deal valued at $400 million.
lead_para: Amazon Web Services, the biggest of the cloud-computing providers, has a new line of work: Taking other cloud-computing giants into other countries.
headline: Salesforce to Use Amazon’s Cloud to Expand in Canada and Australia

abstract: Wall Street is increasingly wary of the amount of equity that publicly traded tech companies award employees, especially when those companies stumble.
lead_para: Tech companies may have to take stock of giving stock.
headline: Tech Companies May Face a New Cost to Paying in Shares

abstract: Through the funds, companies scout for new products or services and business partners, but critics say the funds contribute to inflated valuations.
lead_para: At first glance, the maker of Cheerios and Cocoa Puffs might not fit the image of a cutting-edge venture capital investor.
headline: General Mills and 7-Eleven Join the Venture Capital Crowd

abstract: Adam Bosworth, a tech pioneer, sees the future in servers that manage and learn from data gathered by sensors implanted in practically everything.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — If you have sent email on Google or used Microsoft’s browser or databases, you have touched the technology handiwork of Adam Bosworth.
headline: Looking Beyond the Internet of Things

abstract: The Merger That Wasn’t? | Renaud Laplanche Said to Consider Lending Club Takeover
lead_para: DELL RULING MAY NOT AFFECT BUYOUTS AS MUCH AS FEARED | Will a judge’s ruling that buyers underpaid for Dell when it was taken private change buyouts more broadly? Probably not,Steven Davidoff Solomon argues in the Deal Professor column.
headline: Morning Agenda: Dell Ruling May Not Affect Buyouts as Much as Feared

abstract: Payday Loan Industry Could Soon Be Gutted | Sumner Redstone’s Granddaughter Sides With Viacom Directors
lead_para: UBER RECEIVES $3.5 BILLION FROM SAUDI ARABIA | Uber has turned to the Middle East in its quest to build a global empire. It raised $3.5 billion from Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund in one of the largest ever investments into a privately held start-up,Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced report in The New York Times. This round of fund-raising continued to value the company at $62.5 billion.
headline: Morning Agenda: Uber Receives $3.5 Billion from Saudi Arabia

abstract: The online software company hopes to stimulate growth by buying the e-commerce specialist.
lead_para: Salesforce.com is fluffing up its cloud business, but at a high cost.
headline: Salesforce.com to Acquire Demandware for $2.8 Billion

abstract: The purchase of NetSuite by Oracle makes strategic sense, but Lawrence J. Ellison appears to benefit from a side investment at Oracle’s expense.
lead_para: Lawrence J. Ellison is cashing in again.
headline: Once Again, an Oracle Deal Benefits Ellison

abstract: Salesforce is still in talks to buy Twitter, according to two people involved in the discussions, despite some of Salesforce’s largest shareholders indicating that they are against the deal.
lead_para: Even though some of the largest shareholders in Salesforce.com have made it clear that they are against the deal, the company is still in talks to buy Twitter, according to two people involved in the discussions who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
headline: Morning Agenda: Twitter-Salesforce Talks, Buffett’s Taxes, H.R. Red Flags

abstract: The tech world has been buzzing since it heard that the online software company Salesforce was interested in bidding for Twitter.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Marc Benioff, the founder and chief executive of Salesforce.com, showed up onstage on Wednesday afternoon at his biggest customer event of the year to talk up his business technology company’s products and strategy.
headline: Twitter’s Fate: Marc Benioff of Salesforce Addresses Acquisition Talk

abstract: Theranos was recently a star of Silicon Valley. But now, it is closing its laboratory operations, shutting its wellness centers and laying off 340 employees.
lead_para: Not long ago, Theranos and its founder, Elizabeth Holmes, were stars of Silicon Valley.
headline: Morning Agenda: Theranos Closes Labs, Twitter Chatter, Taking on Samsung

abstract: “While I look at a lot of things, I actually pass on most things,” Marc Benioff said after CNBC's Jim Cramer asked him to deny that his company would buy Twitter.
lead_para: “While I look at a lot of things, I actually pass on most things,” Marc Benioff said after CNBC's Jim Cramer asked him to deny that his company would buy Twitter.
headline: Salesforce C.E.O. on Twitter Deal

abstract: Once so close they flirted with a merger, the software giants became archrivals when they realized the value of the data amassed by social networks.
lead_para: This is a story of love lost after a fight over social media.
headline: How LinkedIn Drove a Wedge Between Microsoft and Salesforce

abstract: Mike calls Yahoo’s surveillance predicament a “flaming garbage fire” and hopes Alexa and her A.I. ilk are friendlier than HAL. Soon, Farhad will be in Asia.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Samsung’s Exploding Products and Twitter’s Fizzling Deal

abstract: Suitors are falling away, and there is no way conventional financial analysis can help any company rationalize an acquisition of the company.
lead_para: Twitter’s openness to being sold has set off a tweetstorm with a direct message: It will be hard for a new owner to make buying the $15 billion social network stack up.
headline: Paying $15 Billion for Twitter Will Be Hard for Anyone to Justify

abstract: Twitter shares tumbled as few deal-making options remained.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter may have to fix its problems on its own, at least for now.
headline: Salesforce Rules Out a Bid for Twitter

abstract: At annual presentations in San Francisco, tech companies deluge potential customers with data on their progress in cloud computing, machine learning and artificial intelligence.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Autumn is a good time to see what is happening next in the $3 trillion business technology market. In particular, it’s a good time to check out what’s new in corporate paranoia.
headline: Taking the Temperature Inside the (Feverish) Cloud

abstract: To make acquisitions, Salesforce relies on stock and therefore needs to keep its shareholders happy. And they are not interested in a Twitter deal.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — The investor pressure began building on Marc Benioff, chief executive of Salesforce.com, two weeks ago.
headline: Salesforce Shareholders Besiege Possible Twitter Deal

abstract: The focus is on currency markets, with the peso rising, indicating traders and investors believe Hillary Clinton’s chances of winning the presidential election are improving.
lead_para: The focus is again on the currency markets, but this time it is not just about the pound.
headline: Morning Agenda: Peso Predictor, Salesforce Investors Speak, Calpers Standoff

abstract: The Galaxy Note 7 smartphone maker halted production after some of the devices caught fire. And Twitter was facing an implosion in potential deal talks.
lead_para: Samsung and Twitter are not tech companies whose names are often uttered in the same breath. But they are connected right now by the theme of explosions.
headline: Earth-Rattling Times at Samsung and Twitter

abstract: They may both be technology companies, but their businesses are vastly different. And history tells us combining very different tech outfits is risky.
lead_para: October in San Francisco is a special time. The fog lifts. The temperature rises. The Blue Angels buzz overhead for Fleet Week as tens of thousands of business technology types descend on the city for Salesforce.com’s annual conference.
headline: Daily Report: Salesforce Has Had Its Eye on Twitter. But Why?

abstract: The search giant is one of several American tech companies facing inspections overseas for the way they do business.
lead_para: Europe has a big headache: the current state of American technology companies. And it may take a long time to go away.
headline: Daily Report: Google’s Day in Europe’s Court Highlights Nature of New Tech

abstract: The company tries to forge ahead despite a constantly shifting chess match of deal discussions and considerations.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last week, Twitter’s fate has appeared to be murkier than ever. The troubled social media company, which has been engaged in talks to sell itself, seemed to be running out of potential buyers.
headline: Twitter Is Said to Be in Continued Talks With Salesforce

abstract: C.E.O.s are speaking out on social and political issues in sometimes startling ways, recasting the role business plays in the national debate.
lead_para: The nation has split into political tribes. The culture wars are back, waged over transgender rights and immigration. White nationalists are on the march.
headline: The Moral Voice of Corporate America

abstract: Salesforce Tower, which at 1,070 feet is the tallest office building west of the Mississippi, will be inhabited in January, signaling tech’s triumph in the city.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — The skyscraper came late to this city, a shipping and manufacturing hub for much of its existence. The wealthy roosted on the hills and the masses toiled on the flats and the docks. Everyone lived close to the ground in a setting renowned for its natural beauty.
headline: San Francisco’s Skyline, Now Inescapably Transformed by Tech

abstract: The Indiana capital is making up for diminished manufacturing by supporting new technology, and workers are won over by low costs and great amenities.
lead_para: When Ashley Zegiestowsky, a computer sciences major at Butler University, was hunting for a technology job during her senior year, she took a close look at Silicon Valley, the promised land for young engineers eager to be part of the next big thing.
headline: How Indianapolis, Long Known as a Manufacturing Center, Is Luring Tech Talent

abstract: Timothy D. Cook of Apple, Ginni Rometty of IBM and dozens of other C.E.O.s said new guidelines and practices were hindering skilled foreign workers and harmful to economic growth.
lead_para: Dozens of American business leaders are challenging the Trump administration over changes to immigration policy that they say threaten the livelihoods of thousands of their skilled foreign workers, and the nation’s economic growth and competitiveness as well.
headline: Top C.E.O.s Denounce Trump Immigration Policy as Threat to U.S. Economy

abstract: Something like this was tried 18 years ago, when AOL bought Time Warner. But Marc Benioff, long a prominent figure in his hometown, does things his own way.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Marc Benioff is like the Salesforce Tower: He looms over this city.
headline: A San Francisco Tech Mogul Buys a Fabled Slice of New York Media

abstract: The storied weekly spent less than a year as part of the Iowa-based Meredith Corporation. Its new owners, Mr. Benioff and his wife, are buying it for $190 million.
lead_para: Time, the pre-eminent weekly newsmagazine of the 20th century, will have new owners: Marc Benioff, the billionaire co-founder of the software company Salesforce, and his wife, Lynne.
headline: Time Magazine Is Bought by Marc Benioff, Salesforce Billionaire

abstract: While having a massage late Sunday, the West Coast-based tech billionaire discussed via text message why he was entering the East Coast-based media industry by acquiring Time Inc.’s flagship publication.
lead_para: Marc Benioff, the chief executive of the software company Salesforce, and his wife, Lynne, said on Sunday that they had agreed to buy Time magazine from Meredith Corporation for $190 million in cash.
headline: Marc Benioff Explains Why He Is Buying Time Magazine

abstract: The decision by the Salesforce chief executive Marc Benioff to buy Time magazine raises the question of the duty that executives have to the companies that made them rich.
lead_para: If Time magazine runs another cover in a series of illustrations showing President Trump’s Oval Office taking on water, employees and shareholders of Salesforce might want to brace for a tweetstorm from the White House — or even calls for regulation of the software company.
headline: When an Owner’s New Company Puts the Old One in Trump’s Cross Hairs

abstract: Marc Benioff has bought Time, becoming the latest technology mogul to invest in a media property.
lead_para: “This is a start-up,” Marc Benioff told me loudly over FaceTime, leaning in and out of the frame on a bumpy ride to the airport. “They have been opportunity constrained,” he said, “but we are here to unshackle them.”
headline: Can the People Who Almost Brought Down the News Business Save It?

abstract: Ken Frazier, Katrina Lake and Marc Benioff will be interviewed for our relaunch of Corner Office. Submit a question for them.
lead_para: The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.
headline: They’re 3 of the U.S.’ Most Innovative C.E.O.s: Ask Them Anything

abstract: Salesforce Chairman and C.E.O. Marc Benioff, speaking at The New York Times’s 2018 New Work Summit, called on leaders to stay involved in guiding the technology their companies create.
lead_para: Salesforce Chairman and C.E.O. Marc Benioff, speaking at The New York Times’s 2018 New Work Summit, called on leaders to stay involved in guiding the technology their companies create.
headline: Marc Benioff on Technology and Trust

abstract: How privacy, security and employee protests will shape the year ahead for Silicon Valley.
lead_para: If you thought 2018 was a bad year for tech, 2019 might turn out to be even worse. This year was filled with revelations about privacy, security and cyberwarfare. Next year, the consequences of those revelations will unfold. And we should be very worried about what the future holds.
headline: The 3 Biggest Challenges for Tech in 2019

abstract: A billionaire tech mogul with a spiritual side, Mr. Benioff riffs on his early days at Apple and Oracle, and what’s wrong with Facebook.
lead_para: Salesforce may not be a household name like Facebook or Twitter, but the software company and its chief executive, Marc Benioff, are hugely influential forces in the technology industry.
headline: Marc Benioff of Salesforce: ‘Are We Not All Connected?’

abstract: The city’s tech elites were divided over the initiative, which is seen as an effort to hold their companies accountable for exacerbating the local housing crisis.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Voters in San Francisco approved a tax increase on the city’s largest businesses that would nearly double its budget for homeless services, a measure seen as an effort to hold wealthy technology companies accountable for exacerbating the local housing crisis.
headline: San Francisco Approves Business Tax to Fund Homeless Services

abstract: I interview C.E.O.s for the business section, and we often end up on the topic of meditation.
lead_para: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.
headline: Talking Mindfulness on the C.E.O. Beat

abstract: By supporting a modest tax increase, companies in San Francisco can help end the city’s homelessness crisis.
lead_para: Back when I was in business school in the 1980s, I was taught — as were generations of aspiring entrepreneurs and executives — that the business of business is business. “There is one and only one social responsibility of business,” the economist Milton Friedman famously wrote in “Capitalism and Freedom”: “to increase its profits.” In an essay for this newspaper in 1970, Dr. Friedman went further, arguing that executives who claim that companies have “responsibilities for providing employment, eliminating discrimination, avoiding pollution and whatever else may be the catchwords” of the day are guilty of “undermining the basis of a free society.”
headline: The Social Responsibility of Business

abstract: Jack Dorsey of Twitter and Marc Benioff of Salesforce, among others, are sparring over a Nov. 6 ballot initiative that would impose new corporate taxes.
lead_para: For months, technology companies in San Francisco have fought a local ballot proposition that would impose taxes on corporations to fund initiatives to help the homeless.
headline: In Liberal San Francisco, Tech Leaders Brawl Over Tax Proposal to Aid Homeless

abstract: The tech industry is caught in the middle of escalating trade tensions with China. And at home, regulators are getting serious about cracking down on Big Tech.
lead_para: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: The Week in Tech: Big Trouble With Trustbusters and China

abstract: Salesforce’s deal to buy the business tools maker Tableau, its largest ever acquisition, was pushed by the need to make business information understandable.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Technology vendors have been going on for years about the rising value of data. But information that can’t be understood is not worth much.
headline: Making Data Coherent Drives Salesforce’s $15.3 Billion Deal for Tableau

abstract: Learn three strategies that sales leaders use to make their teams more efficient, responsive, and adaptive.
lead_para: If you ask CEOs what their most pressing priority is, the majority will answer in one word: growth. They promise their investors that they will increase revenue at twice the market average (according to Bain research). But at the same time, less than two-thirds of their salespeople are hitting their quotas. So how do CEOs meet their investors’ expectations?
headline: Take the Guesswork Out of Growth

abstract: Businesses had plenty of reasons to worry in the first half — from slowing economic growth to geopolitical tensions — but they looked beyond those factors to strike big deals at a record pace.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: $2 Trillion Worth of Deals Were Struck in the First Half of 2019, but Caution Crept In

abstract: The current system has led to profound inequality. To fix it, we need businesses and executives to value purpose alongside profit.
lead_para: Capitalism, I acknowledge, has been good to me.
headline: Marc Benioff: We Need a New Capitalism

abstract: The economist taught a generation of corporate leaders that profit should be their main motive. A new group of C.E.O.s begs to differ.
lead_para: On September 13, 1970, the New York Times Magazine published an essay by the economist Milton Friedman titled “The Social Responsibility of Business is to Increase Its Profits.” It laid out what came to be known as the Friedman Doctrine — a call to arms for American free-market capitalism and arguably the most consequential economic idea, for better or worse, of the latter part of the 20th century.
headline: Has Business Left Milton Friedman Behind?

abstract: Pandemic policies at tech companies have created a rift between parents offered more benefits and resentful workers who don’t have children.
lead_para: OAKLAND, Calif. — When the coronavirus closed schools and child care centers and turned American parenthood into a multitasking nightmare, many tech companies rushed to help their employees. They used their comfortable profit margins to extend workers new benefits, including extra time off for parents to help them care for their children.
headline: Parents Got More Time Off. Then the Backlash Started.

abstract: The pandemic and the movement for racial justice have tested corporate pledges to elevate social concerns alongside shareholder interests. A new study finds companies are failing to follow through.
lead_para: Marc Benioff, chief executive of the technology giant Salesforce, presents himself as an evangelist for stakeholder capitalism: the idea that companies must elevate the interests of workers, the environment and local communities alongside shareholders.
headline: Stakeholder Capitalism Gets a Report Card. It’s Not Good.

abstract: A tech billionaire’s PowerPoint brought the Trillion Trees climate plan to the president, a textbook case of ad hoc policymaking in the Trump era.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — People warned Marc Benioff, the billionaire chief executive of Salesforce, not to bother talking to the White House about global warming. But Mr. Benioff, a tech mogul and environmental philanthropist, felt sure he had found a climate change solution that even President Trump could love: Planting trees.
headline: A Trillion Trees: How One Idea Triumphed Over Trump’s Climate Denialism

abstract: As chief executives hunker down during the pandemic, home offices have become corporate headquarters.
lead_para: On Thursday morning, Chuck Robbins, the chief executive of Cisco, signed on to an companywide video conference from his home office in Silicon Valley. The connection was stable, but the quality was not great.
headline: Logged On From the Laundry Room: How the C.E.O.s of Google, Pfizer and Slack Work From Home

abstract: Will the company’s chief executive, Jack Dorsey, lose his job?
lead_para: Elon Musk was right in his tweet this week: Jack Dorsey does have a “good ❤️.” Mr. Dorsey is indeed one of the more thoughtful, responsive and earnest entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley.
headline: Brace Yourself for What’s Coming at Twitter

abstract: The Salesforce C.E.O.’s planned acquisition of Slack will have him competing directly with the Goliath that is Microsoft.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Five years ago, Marc Benioff negotiated to sell Salesforce, the software company he co-founded in 1999 and has run ever since, to Microsoft. If the deal had gone through, he would have been richly rewarded — but, in the end, just another employee of the tech colossus.
headline: Marc Benioff Sets His Sights on Microsoft

abstract: The person writing the check is still the most important customer.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Why Your Workplace Software Stinks

abstract: The move caps an acquisitive streak by Salesforce and ends Slack’s run as an independent publicly traded company.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Salesforce said on Tuesday that it would buy the workplace software company Slack for $27.7 billion in cash and stock, the latest in a wave of deals as the coronavirus pandemic boosts demand for tools that enable people to work remotely.
headline: Salesforce to Acquire Slack for $27.7 Billion

abstract: Symptom-checking apps and fever-screening cameras promise to keep sick workers at home and hinder the virus. But experts warn they can be inaccurate and violate privacy.
lead_para: Bob Grewal recently began testing a new health-screening setup for workers at a Subway restaurant he owns in Los Angeles near the University of Southern California.
headline: Employers Rush to Adopt Virus Screening. The Tools May Not Help Much.

abstract: A call from a university chancellor set in motion a private-sector effort to procure 50 million masks, gowns and swabs for American medical facilities.
lead_para: Sam Hawgood, the chancellor of the University of California, San Francisco, was getting concerned.
headline: Marc Benioff’s $25 Million Blitz to Buy Protective Gear From China

abstract: People and companies with vested interest in sustaining the U.S.-China relationship are stepping in as ties fray between the two countries.
lead_para: HONG KONG — U.S. hospitals and state officials face desperate shortages of the masks, ventilators and other gear they need to fight the coronavirus. Chinese factories can make the equipment and sell it to them, but huge obstacles stand in the way — and Washington’s stumbles and growing hostility with Beijing aren’t helping.
headline: Frantic for Coronavirus Gear, Americans in Need Turn to China’s Elite

abstract: Marc Benioff, Tim Cook and others are applying their clout to critical supply shortages.
lead_para: Good morning. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)
headline: Salesforce and Other Silicon Valley Firms Are Using Corporate Connections to Buy Masks for Hospitals

abstract: As the COVID-19 crisis continues to evolve, health systems everywhere are under significant strain.
lead_para: As the COVID-19 crisis continues to evolve, health systems everywhere are under significant strain.
headline: Traction on Demand Releases Global Outbreak Response Tool for Free

abstract: A new exhibition in San Francisco makes art out of the Patagonia vest, the former prime minister of England and … Salesforce?
lead_para: The death knell of the Patagonia vest, at least as a symbol of utopianism co-opted by the tech and venture capital world and transformed into shorthand for a certain kind of unbridled corporate power, was much predicted last summer.
headline: Tech Bro Uniform Meets Margaret Thatcher. Disruption Ensues.

abstract: Companies like Salesforce created workplaces with all the comforts of home. But now they may feel more like hospitals.
lead_para: When employees at Salesforce, the cloud software giant based in San Francisco, eventually return to their office towers, they may find that the fun is gone from their famously fun-loving workplaces.
headline: Farewell to Gummy Bear Jars: Tech Offices Get a Virus Safety Makeover

abstract: Salesforce’s approach for Slack is a sign of things to come.
lead_para: Salesforce has approached Slack about a deal, DealBook hears, confirming a report in The Wall Street Journal. A takeover could be announced as soon as this week. The potential deal is a bet on remote working, an area that bankers tell us will be a hot spot for consolidation in the months ahead, as highly valued software companies look to roll up the fragmented market for collaboration tools.
headline: Companies Bet Big on Working From Home

abstract: There’s a hidden hurdle.
lead_para: Business leaders, investors and regulators are all pushing to make corporate America’s boardrooms more diverse. But as a Salesforce executive learned, there are sometimes hidden hurdles to making that happen, Andrew writes in his latest column.
headline: What’s Delaying Boardroom Diversity

abstract: Some companies are reluctant to let lower-level managers become outside directors, adding a systemic impediment to the push.
lead_para: Last spring, Niki Christoff, a senior Salesforce executive, was offered an opportunity to join the board of a publicly traded company alongside her day job. Being a director of a public company is a corporate badge of honor, and the invitation signaled she was poised to break into a club long dominated by men.
headline: A Hidden Hurdle in Efforts to Diversify Boardrooms

abstract: Companies including HP, Microsoft and Unilever are calling for expanded voting access in the state after weeks of silence from national businesses on Republicans’ voting bills there.
lead_para: Two broad coalitions of companies and executives released letters on Tuesday calling for expanded voting access in Texas, wading into the contentious debate over Republican legislators’ proposed new restrictions on balloting after weeks of relative silence from the business community in the state.
headline: Business Coalitions Speak Out Against Voting Restrictions in Texas

abstract: The effort seeks to rally more than $1 billion for countries that can show they are lowering emissions by protecting tropical forests
lead_para: Britain, Norway and the United States said Thursday they would join forces with some of the world’s biggest companies in an effort to rally more than $1 billion for countries that can show they are lowering emissions by protecting tropical forests.
headline: Britain, Norway and the United States join forces with businesses to protect tropical forests.

abstract: See how Salesforce empowers Twitter to help users remain connected and keep conversations going.
headline: The Future of Twitter

abstract: The drug company Eli Lilly said it “will be forced” to look outside the state for employment growth. The engine maker Cummins said the law will “impede our ability to attract and retain top talent.”
lead_para: On Friday, the governor of Indiana signed into law a near-total abortion ban, making the state the first to approve sweeping new restrictions since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June.
headline: Major Indiana Employers Criticize State’s New Abortion Law

abstract: Even as they allow some employees to change how often they come into the office, tech companies are rapidly buying and leasing properties around the country.
lead_para: TEMPE, Ariz. — Early in the pandemic, when shops along Mill Avenue in downtown Tempe closed their doors and students at nearby Arizona State University were asked to go home, the roar of construction continued to fill the air. Now, gleaming in the sunlight and stuffed with amenities, towering glass office buildings have sprouted up all over the Phoenix metropolitan area.
headline: Big Tech Makes a Big Bet: Offices Are Still the Future

abstract: Crypto, the economy, China, streaming wars, Elon Musk and other big topics dominated this year’s DealBook Summit.
lead_para: DealBook held its annual conference in New York yesterday, a packed day of high-level discussions with leaders from the world of politics, business and culture. Speakers included:
headline: What We Learned From Sam Bankman-Fried, Mark Zuckerberg, Reed Hastings and More

abstract: Stewart Butterfield, the chief executive of Slack, which is owned by Salesforce, is the latest to announce an exit from Salesforce in recent weeks.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Stewart Butterfield, the chief executive of Slack, a workplace communication platform owned by Salesforce, said on Monday that he would leave his position in January.
headline: Slack C.E.O. to Step Down in January

abstract: The European Union is crying foul over the Inflation Reduction Act, saying the billions in climate subsidies it offers create a trade imbalance.
lead_para: Europe is growing hot over the Biden administration’s Inflation Reduction Act, with opposition to the sweeping climate and economic bill dominating the U.S.-EU Trade and Technology Council talks this week. Some analysts fear the disagreement could thrust two of the world’s biggest trading partners into a new economic war.
headline: Could Biden’s Climate Agenda Trigger a New Trade War?

abstract: Prices of digital currencies have tumbled even after the exchange FTX announced a provisional lifeline by a top rival, Binance.
lead_para: Devastation in the crypto market continued on Wednesday, after the giant crypto exchange Binance announced a bombshell deal to buy its embattled rival, FTX. (The deal excludes FTX’s American operations.) The entire market’s capitalization now stands at $900 billion, down from $3 trillion just one year ago, while major cryptocurrencies were down by double-digit percentages. The damage is largely contained within crypto; both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq closed up yesterday.
headline: Crypto Investors Grapple With the Collapse of a Giant

abstract: Bret Taylor, an understated executive, led talks with Elon Musk over his plans to acquire the company and the legal fight to seal the deal.
lead_para: On a Friday morning in September, about a month before an expected courtroom fight to decide the future of Twitter, Bret Taylor walked into the company’s offices in New York City to lead only the second in-person meeting of its board of directors since the start of the pandemic.
headline: The Board Chair Squaring Up to Elon Musk in the Feud Over Twitter

abstract: Secular companies have invited employees to bring their “whole selves” to work. That increasingly includes their religion.
lead_para: When Christy Childers moved from Austin to San Francisco in 2017 to start a marketing job at Facebook, she felt anxious about sharing her evangelical faith with her new colleagues. In Ms. Childers’s religious community, Silicon Valley has a reputation for being overtly secular and less than accepting of Christian beliefs. She now calls that view “unfounded.” Within a week, colleagues had invited her to a lunchtime Bible study and a happy hour attended by scores of Christians across the tech industry.
headline: What Happens When the Boss Invites You to Bible Study?

abstract: The chief executive, under pressure from activist investors, seeks to do well and do good — but his options are narrowing.
lead_para: Many years ago, Thich Nhat Hanh, the Buddhist monk and spiritual leader, posed a question to Marc Benioff, the co-founder and chief executive of Salesforce.
headline: Happiness or Success? Salesforce’s Marc Benioff Doesn’t Want to Choose.

abstract: The software giant faces mounting pressure from activist investors and pushback from employees unhappy about a wave of firings and the scaling back of office perks.
lead_para: Wednesday’s earnings report by Salesforce may be the most closely watched in the software giant’s 24-year history. Investors — especially the now half-dozen activist shareholders who are clamoring for change at the company, and possibly board seats — will be eager to hear how its chief, Marc Benioff, plans to turn around its fortunes.
headline: The Heat on Salesforce Grows Ahead of a Big Earnings Call

abstract: The White House is at odds with business leaders over share repurchase programs. DealBook digs into the numbers to see who’s gaining from the practice.
lead_para: Share buybacks provided plenty of big headlines this week.
headline: The Trillion-Dollar Debate Over Share Buybacks

abstract: President Biden is expected to use his first veto to protect environmental, social and corporate governance investment considerations in retirement plans.
lead_para: Senate Republicans, helped by two Democratic defectors, voted on Wednesday to block a Labor Department rule allowing retirement plan managers to include environmental, social and corporate governance considerations (E.S.G., for short) in their investment plans.
headline: The Battle Over E.S.G. Heads to the White House

abstract: First Citizens agreed on Sunday to acquire the failed lender’s retail operations. Will the move convince investors that recent turmoil in the sector is over?
lead_para: First Citizens agreed on Sunday night to buy most of Silicon Valley Bank at a discount, clearing the way for the U.S. banking industry to potentially move on from the turmoil set off by the collapse of the tech-focused lender.
headline: Markets Climb as Silicon Valley Bank Finally Finds a Buyer

abstract: The layoffs will focus on human resources and its retail division, Amazon’s chief executive said in an email to employees.
lead_para: Amazon plans to eliminate 18,000 corporate and technology jobs in a significant expansion of its cost-cutting plans, the company’s chief executive, Andy Jassy, said in a message to employees on Wednesday.
headline: Amazon Expands Corporate Layoffs to 18,000 Jobs

abstract: To land the House speaker position, the California Republican will have to win over opponents who question his ties to Silicon Valley and his commitment to right wing causes.
lead_para: Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, is still working on landing the House speaker gig after six failed attempts. It’s the first such House floor showdown in a century, and business is at the heart of his woes.
headline: Kevin McCarthy’s Business Ties Complicate His Rise to Power

abstract: The company’s grip on ticket sales, and its move last year to cancel sales for Taylor Swift’s upcoming tour, will be a big focus of an antitrust-focused hearing.
lead_para: Two months after Ticketmaster canceled sales for Taylor Swift’s upcoming Eras tour, a top executive from its parent company, Live Nation Entertainment, will appear at the Senate on Tuesday to defend the company. (Ms. Swift herself is not scheduled to show up.)
headline: Live Nation Faces a Skeptical Senate

abstract: Elliott Management, the $55 billion hedge fund, has taken a big stake in the struggling tech giant, putting more pressure on its co-founder, Marc Benioff.
lead_para: Salesforce has been through a lot of turbulence lately, including a huge round of layoffs and a shake-up in its top ranks. Now it faces a big new threat in Elliott Management, the $55 billion hedge fund that has taken a significant stake in the company.
headline: Activist Investors Are Circling Salesforce

abstract: The software company plans to cut around 8,000 jobs as business slows for tech companies. “We hired too many people leading into this economic downturn,” Salesforce’s chief executive said.
lead_para: Salesforce, the business software giant, said on Wednesday that it planned to lay off 10 percent of its work force, or about 8,000 employees, and scale back office space because of concerns about the economy.
headline: Salesforce to Lay Off 10% of Staff and Cut Office Space

abstract: Hindenburg Research accused the Adani Group of orchestrating the “largest con in corporate history,”  sending shares of its companies tumbling on Wednesday.
lead_para: Hindenburg Research, the short seller that rose to prominence by going after unprofitable blank-check firms and crypto companies, is pursuing its biggest targets yet: the Indian conglomerate Adani Group and its billionaire founder, Gautam Adani, whom Forbes ranks as the world’s third-richest person.
headline: A Short Seller Takes Aim at an Indian Corporate Giant

abstract: The next stage of getting workers back at their desks includes incentives like $10 to the charity of their choice — and consequences like poor performance evaluations if they don’t make the trek in.
lead_para: Manny Medina, the chief executive of a Seattle-based artificial intelligence sales company, doesn’t mind repeating himself. It comes with the territory, after all. That tolerance proved convenient this year as he faced the same question innumerable times.
headline: Return to Office Enters the Desperation Phase

abstract: Many businesses have adopted policies to diversify hiring but the Supreme Court’s ruling to end the policy in universities endangers those efforts.
lead_para: The Supreme Court’s decision on Thursday to strike down affirmative action at colleges and universities sent shock waves throughout higher education. But the effects of the 6-3 ruling, which found that race-conscious admissions programs were unlawful, promise to go much wider.
headline: Why Corporate America Is Worried About Affirmative Action

abstract: After years of steady growth, many technology companies are laying off workers and giving up millions of square feet of office space in the city.
lead_para: For much of the last two decades, including during the pandemic, technology companies were a bright spot in New York’s economy, adding thousands of high-paying jobs and expanding into millions of square feet of office space.
headline: Tech Firms Once Powered New York’s Economy. Now They’re Scaling Back.

abstract: Amazon, Box, Salesforce, Oracle and others have recently rolled out A.I.-related products to help workplaces become more efficient and productive.
lead_para: Earlier this year, Mark Austin, the vice president of data science at AT&T, noticed that some of the company’s developers had started using the ChatGPT chatbot at work. When the developers got stuck, they asked ChatGPT to explain, fix or hone their code.
headline: As Businesses Clamor for Workplace A.I., Tech Companies Rush to Provide It

abstract: OpenAI’s intricate structure, which contributed to the ouster of Sam Altman, is complex by design.
lead_para: The future of OpenAI, whose ChatGPT kick-started an arms race in artificial intelligence, has grown even cloudier. A majority of its workers called on its board to resign after ousting Sam Altman as C.E.O. over how fast to commercialize its technology.
headline: Does A.I. Have an Inherent Governance Problem?
